defs.docs: A small and fast async runtime.

attributes.value: ! A small and fast async runtime.
! There are three executors that poll futures:
! 1. Thread-local executor for tasks created by [`Task::local()`].
! 2. Work-stealing executor for tasks created by [`Task::spawn()`].
! 3. Blocking executor for tasks created by [`Task::blocking()`], [`blocking!`], [`iter()`],
! Blocking executor is the only one that spawns threads on its own.
! See [here](fn.run.html#examples) for how to run executors on a single thread or on a thread
! To wait for the next I/O event, the reactor calls [epoll] on Linux/Android, [kqueue] on
! The [`Async`] type registers I/O handles in the reactor and is able to convert their blocking
! The [`Timer`] type registers timers in the reactor that will fire at the chosen points in
! Function [`run()`] simultaneously runs the thread-local executor, runs the work-stealing
! executor, and polls the reactor for I/O events and timers. At least one thread has to be
! calling [`run()`] in order for futures waiting on I/O and timers to get notified.
! If you want a multithreaded runtime, just call [`run()`] from multiple threads. See
! There is also [`block_on()`], which blocks the current thread until a future completes, but it
! doesn't poll the reactor or run executors. When using [`block_on()`], make sure at least one
! thread is calling [`run()`], or else I/O and timers will not work!
! Blocking tasks run in the background on a dedicated thread pool.
! Connect to a HTTP website, make a GET request, and pipe the response to the standard output:

!         let req = b"GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Connection: close

";
! Look inside the [examples] directory for more:
! It's also possible to plug non-async libraries into the runtime: see
! Finally, there's an [example][other-runtimes] showing how to use smol with

defs.name: Async
defs.docs: Async I/O.

attributes.value: / This type converts a blocking I/O type into an async type, provided it is supported by
/ I/O operations can then be *asyncified* by methods [`Async::with()`] and [`Async::with_mut()`],
/ or you can use the predefined async methods on the standard networking types.
/ **NOTE**: Do not use this type with [`File`][`std::fs::File`], [`Stdin`][`std::io::Stdin`],
/ instead to read/write on a thread.
/ To make an async I/O handle cloneable, wrap it in [piper]'s `Arc`:
/ // Create two handles to the stream.
/ // Echo all messages from the read side of the stream into the write side.
/ If a type does but its reference doesn't implement [`AsyncRead`] and [`AsyncWrite`], wrap it in
/ // Reads data from a stream and echoes it back.
/ async fn echo(stream: impl AsyncRead + AsyncWrite + Unpin) -> std::io::Result<u64> {
/     // Create two handles to the stream.
/     // Echo all messages from the read side of the stream into the write side.
/ // Connect to a local server and echo its messages back.

attributes.value: / This function will put the handle in non-blocking mode and register it in [epoll] on
/ Linux/Android, [kqueue] on macOS/iOS/BSD, or [wepoll] on Windows.
/ On Unix systems, the handle must implement `AsRawFd`, while on Windows it must implement
/ If the handle implements [`Read`] and [`Write`], then `Async<T>` automatically
/ Other I/O operations can be *asyncified* by methods [`Async::with()`] and

attributes.value: / Waits until the I/O handle is readable.
/ This function completes when a read operation on this I/O handle wouldn't block.
/ // Wait until a client can be accepted.

defs.name: read_with
defs.value: fn <R> (&self, op: impl FnMut(&T) -> io::Result<R>) -> io::Result<R>
defs.docs: Performs a read operation asynchronously.

attributes.value: / The I/O handle is registered in the reactor and put in non-blocking mode. This function
/ invokes the `op` closure in a loop until it succeeds or returns an error other than
/ [`io::ErrorKind::WouldBlock`]. In between iterations of the loop, it waits until the OS
/ sends a notification that the I/O handle is readable.
/ The closure receives a shared reference to the I/O handle.

defs.docs: Performs a read operation asynchronously.

/ The closure receives a mutable reference to the I/O handle.

defs.name: block_on
defs.docs: Blocks on a single future.

attributes.value: / This function polls the future in a loop, parking the current thread after each step to wait
/ Unlike [`run()`], it does not run executors or poll the reactor!
/ You can think of it as the easiest and most efficient way of turning an async operation into a
/ // Run executors and the reactor on a separeate thread, forever.
/     // This timer only works because there's a thread calling `run()`.

defs.value: fn <T> (iter: impl Iterator<Item = T> + Send + 'static) -> impl Stream<Item = T> + Send + Unpin + 'static
defs.docs: Creates a stream that iterates on a thread.

attributes.value: / Creates a stream that iterates on a thread.
/ This adapter converts any kind of synchronous iterator into an asynchronous stream by running
/ it on the blocking executor and sending items back over a channel.
/ List files in the current directory:
/ // Iterate over the contents of the directory.

defs.name: reader
defs.value: fn (reader: impl Read + Send + 'static) -> impl AsyncRead + Send + Unpin + 'static
defs.docs: Creates an async reader that runs on a thread.

attributes.value: / Creates an async reader that runs on a thread.
/ This adapter converts any kind of synchronous reader into an asynchronous reader by running it
/ on the blocking executor and sending bytes back over a pipe.
/ // Spawn a child process and make an async reader for its stdout.

defs.name: writer
defs.value: fn (writer: impl Write + Send + 'static) -> impl AsyncWrite + Send + Unpin + 'static
defs.docs: Creates an async writer that runs on a thread.

attributes.value: / Creates an async writer that runs on a thread.
/ This adapter converts any kind of synchronous writer into an asynchronous writer by running it
/ on the blocking executor and receiving bytes over a pipe.
/ **Note:** Don't forget to flush the writer at the end, or some written bytes might get lost!
/ // Write some bytes into the file and flush.
/ // Create an async writer to stdout.

defs.name: run
defs.docs: Runs executors and polls the reactor.

attributes.value: / Runs executors and polls the reactor.
/ This function simultaneously runs the thread-local executor, runs the work-stealing
/ executor, and polls the reactor for I/O events and timers. At least one thread has to be
/ calling [`run()`] in order for futures waiting on I/O and timers to get notified.
/ // Run the thread-local and work-stealing executor on the current thread.
/ // Same number of threads as there are CPU cores.
/ // Run the thread-local and work-stealing executor on a thread pool.
/     // A pending future is one that simply yields forever.
/ // No need to `run()`, now we can just block on the main future.
/ // Same number of threads as there are CPU cores.
/ // A channel that sends the shutdown signal.
/     // Spawn an executor thread that waits for the shutdown signal.
/ // No need to `run()`, now we can just block on the main future.

defs.name: Task
defs.docs: A spawned future.

attributes.value: / Tasks are also futures themselves and yield the output of the spawned future.
/ When a task is dropped, its gets canceled and won't be polled again. To cancel a task a bit
/ more gracefully and wait until it stops running, use the [`cancel()`][Task::cancel()] method.
/ Tasks that panic get immediately canceled. Awaiting a canceled task also causes a panic.
/ If the future panics, the panic will be unwound into the [`run()`] invocation that polled it.
/ However, this does not apply to the blocking executor - it will simply ignore panics and
/ // Spawn a task onto the work-stealing executor.
/ // Wait for the task to complete.

must_use =
  "tasks get canceled when dropped, use `.detach()` to run them in the background"

defs.name: local
defs.docs: Spawns a future onto the thread-local executor.

attributes.value: / Spawns a future onto the thread-local executor.
/ Panics if the current thread is not inside an invocation of [`run()`].

defs.name: spawn
defs.value: fn (future: impl Future<Output = T> + Send + 'static) -> Task<T>
defs.docs: Spawns a future onto the work-stealing executor.

attributes.value: / Spawns a future onto the work-stealing executor.
/ This future may be stolen and polled by any thread calling [`run()`].

defs.name: blocking
defs.value: fn (future: impl Future<Output = T> + Send + 'static) -> Task<T>
defs.docs: Spawns a future onto the blocking executor.

attributes.value: / Spawns a future onto the blocking executor.
/ This future is allowed to block for an indefinite length of time.
/ For convenience, there is also the [`blocking!`] macro that spawns a blocking tasks and
/ Read a line from the standard input:

defs.name: unwrap
defs.docs: Spawns a new task that awaits and unwraps the result.

attributes.value: / Spawns a new task that awaits and unwraps the result.
/ The new task will panic if the original task results in an error.

defs.name: expect
defs.docs: Spawns a new task that awaits and unwraps the result.

attributes.value: / Spawns a new task that awaits and unwraps the result.
/ The new task will panic with the provided message if the original task results in an error.

defs.name: detach
defs.docs: Detaches the task to let it keep running in the background.

attributes.value: / Detaches the task to let it keep running in the background.
/         println!("I'm a daemon task looping forever.");

defs.name: cancel
defs.docs: Cancels the task and waits for it to stop running.

attributes.value: / Cancels the task and waits for it to stop running.
/ Returns the task's output if it was completed just before it got canceled, or `None` if it
/ While it's possible to simply drop the [`Task`] to cancel it, this is a cleaner way of
/ canceling because it also waits for the task to stop running.
/         println!("Even though I'm in an infinite loop, you can still cancel me!");

defs.name: Timer
defs.docs: Fires at the chosen point in time.

attributes.value: / Fires at the chosen point in time.
/ Timers are futures that output the [`Instant`] at which they fired.
/ Set a timeout on an I/O operation:
